bestBHT.bht: Jesus forewarns his disciples that they will face betrayal and the risk of death, not only from strangers but also from their own loved ones. The examples of James, who was put to death (Acts 12:2), and Stephen, who was stoned to death (Acts 7:59-60), highlight the grave consequences of their faithfulness. It is said that all of the Apostles, besides John, eventually faced martyrdom. This solemn warning reminds us of the immense sacrifice and unwavering commitment that following Jesus may demand.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 21:16, Jesus warns his disciples that they will face betrayal, even from their own loved ones. As Bengel points out, this betrayal will not only come from strangers but also from their closest relationships, as indicated by the mention of parents, brethren, kinsfolks, and friends. This warning rings true, as we see through the examples of James who was put to death (Acts 12:2), and Stephen who was stoned to death (Matthew 10:21, Acts 7:59-60). In fact, according to some commentators, all of the Apostles, except for John, were eventually martyred. This verse serves as a reminder that following Jesus may come at a great cost, even requiring the ultimate sacrifice.

Following Jesus comes at a tremendous cost, requiring complete devotion even in the face of betrayal and persecution.
